trans-unit.source: App Model v2.0 Protocols | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: App Model v2.0 Protocols | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: The protocols supported by the Azure AD v2.0 app model public preview.
trans-unit.target: The protocols supported by the Azure AD v2.0 app model public preview.

trans-unit.source: App model v2.0 preview: Protocols - OAuth 2.0 & OpenID Connect
trans-unit.target: App model v2.0 preview: Protocols - OAuth 2.0 & OpenID Connect

trans-unit.source: The v2.0 app model provides identity-as-a-service for your apps by supporting industry standard protocols, OpenID Connect and OAuth 2.0.
trans-unit.target: The v2.0 app model provides identity-as-a-service for your apps by supporting industry standard protocols, OpenID Connect and OAuth 2.0.

trans-unit.source: While the service is standard compliant, there can be subtle differences between any two implementations of these protocols.
trans-unit.target: While the service is standard compliant, there can be subtle differences between any two implementations of these protocols.

trans-unit.source: The information here will be useful if you choose to write your code by directly sending & handling HTTP requests, rather than using one of our open source libraries.
trans-unit.target: The information here will be useful if you choose to write your code by directly sending & handling HTTP requests, rather than using one of our open source libraries.

trans-unit.source: This information applies to the v2.0 app model public preview.
trans-unit.target: This information applies to the v2.0 app model public preview.

trans-unit.source: For instructions on how to integrate with the generally available Azure AD service, please refer to the [Azure Active Directory Developer Guide](active-directory-developers-guide.md).
trans-unit.target: For instructions on how to integrate with the generally available Azure AD service, please refer to the [Azure Active Directory Developer Guide](active-directory-developers-guide.md).

trans-unit.source: The Basics
trans-unit.target: The Basics

trans-unit.source: Every app that uses the v2.0 app model will need to be registered at [apps.dev.microsoft.com](https://apps.dev.microsoft.com).
trans-unit.target: Every app that uses the v2.0 app model will need to be registered at [apps.dev.microsoft.com](https://apps.dev.microsoft.com).

trans-unit.source: The app registration process will collect & assign a few values to your app:
trans-unit.target: The app registration process will collect & assign a few values to your app:

trans-unit.source: An **Application Id** that uniquely identifies your app
trans-unit.target: An **Application Id** that uniquely identifies your app

trans-unit.source: A **Redirect URI** or **Package Identifier** that can be used to direct responses back to your app
trans-unit.target: A **Redirect URI** or **Package Identifier** that can be used to direct responses back to your app

trans-unit.source: A few other scenario-specific values.
trans-unit.target: A few other scenario-specific values.

trans-unit.source: For more detail, learn how to [register an app](active-directory-v2-app-registration.md).
trans-unit.target: For more detail, learn how to [register an app](active-directory-v2-app-registration.md).

trans-unit.source: Once registered, the app communicates with Azure AD my sending requests to the v2.0 endpoint:
trans-unit.target: Once registered, the app communicates with Azure AD my sending requests to the v2.0 endpoint:

trans-unit.source: In nearly all OAuth & OpenID Connect flows, there are four parties involved in the exchange:
trans-unit.target: In nearly all OAuth & OpenID Connect flows, there are four parties involved in the exchange:

trans-unit.source: OAuth 2.0 Roles
trans-unit.target: OAuth 2.0 Roles

trans-unit.source: The **Authorization Server** is the v2.0 Endpoint.
trans-unit.target: The **Authorization Server** is the v2.0 Endpoint.

trans-unit.source: It is responsible for ensuring the user's identity, granting and revoking access to resources, and issuing tokens.
trans-unit.target: It is responsible for ensuring the user's identity, granting and revoking access to resources, and issuing tokens.

trans-unit.source: It is also known as the identity provider - it securely handles anything to do with the user's information, their access, and the trust relationships between parties in an flow.
trans-unit.target: It is also known as the identity provider - it securely handles anything to do with the user's information, their access, and the trust relationships between parties in an flow.

trans-unit.source: The **Resource Owner** is typically the end-user.
trans-unit.target: The **Resource Owner** is typically the end-user.

trans-unit.source: It is the party that owns the data, and has the power to allow third parties to access that data, or resource.
trans-unit.target: It is the party that owns the data, and has the power to allow third parties to access that data, or resource.

trans-unit.source: The **OAuth Client** is your app, identified by its Application Id.
trans-unit.target: The **OAuth Client** is your app, identified by its Application Id.

trans-unit.source: It is usually the party that the end-user interacts with, and it requests tokens from the authorization server.
trans-unit.target: It is usually the party that the end-user interacts with, and it requests tokens from the authorization server.

trans-unit.source: The client must be granted permission to access the resource by the resource owner.
trans-unit.target: The client must be granted permission to access the resource by the resource owner.

trans-unit.source: The **Resource Server** is where the resource or data resides.
trans-unit.target: The **Resource Server** is where the resource or data resides.

trans-unit.source: It trusts the Authorization Server to securely authenticate and authorize the OAuth Client, and uses Bearer access_tokens to ensure that access to a resource can be granted.
trans-unit.target: It trusts the Authorization Server to securely authenticate and authorize the OAuth Client, and uses Bearer access_tokens to ensure that access to a resource can be granted.

trans-unit.source: Tokens
trans-unit.target: Tokens

trans-unit.source: The v2.0 app model's implementation of OAuth 2.0 and OpenID Connect make extensive use of bearer tokens, including bearer tokens represented as JWTs.
trans-unit.target: The v2.0 app model's implementation of OAuth 2.0 and OpenID Connect make extensive use of bearer tokens, including bearer tokens represented as JWTs.

trans-unit.source: A bearer token is a lightweight security token that grants the “bearer” access to a protected resource.
trans-unit.target: A bearer token is a lightweight security token that grants the “bearer” access to a protected resource.

trans-unit.source: In this sense, the “bearer” is any party that can present the token.
trans-unit.target: In this sense, the “bearer” is any party that can present the token.

trans-unit.source: Though a party must first authenticate with Azure AD to receive the bearer token, if the required steps are not taken to secure the token in transmission and storage, it can be intercepted and used by an unintended party.
trans-unit.target: Though a party must first authenticate with Azure AD to receive the bearer token, if the required steps are not taken to secure the token in transmission and storage, it can be intercepted and used by an unintended party.

trans-unit.source: While some security tokens have a built-in mechanism for preventing unauthorized parties from using them, bearer tokens do not have this mechanism and must be transported in a secure channel such as transport layer security (HTTPS).
trans-unit.target: While some security tokens have a built-in mechanism for preventing unauthorized parties from using them, bearer tokens do not have this mechanism and must be transported in a secure channel such as transport layer security (HTTPS).

trans-unit.source: If a bearer token is transmitted in the clear, a man-in the middle attack can be used by a malicious party to acquire the token and use it for an unauthorized access to a protected resource.
trans-unit.target: If a bearer token is transmitted in the clear, a man-in the middle attack can be used by a malicious party to acquire the token and use it for an unauthorized access to a protected resource.

trans-unit.source: The same security principles apply when storing or caching bearer tokens for later use.
trans-unit.target: The same security principles apply when storing or caching bearer tokens for later use.

trans-unit.source: Always ensure that your app transmits and stores bearer tokens in a secure manner.
trans-unit.target: Always ensure that your app transmits and stores bearer tokens in a secure manner.

trans-unit.source: For more security considerations on bearer tokens, see [RFC 6750 Section 5](http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6750).
trans-unit.target: For more security considerations on bearer tokens, see [RFC 6750 Section 5](http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6750).

trans-unit.source: Further details of different types of tokens used in the v2.0 app model is available in [the v2.0 app model token reference](active-directory-v2-tokens.md).
trans-unit.target: Further details of different types of tokens used in the v2.0 app model is available in [the v2.0 app model token reference](active-directory-v2-tokens.md).

trans-unit.source: Protocols
trans-unit.target: Protocols

trans-unit.source: If you're ready to see some example requests, get started with one of the below tutorials.
trans-unit.target: If you're ready to see some example requests, get started with one of the below tutorials.

trans-unit.source: Each one corresponds to a particular authentication scenario.
trans-unit.target: Each one corresponds to a particular authentication scenario.

trans-unit.source: If you need help determining which is the right flow for you,
trans-unit.target: If you need help determining which is the right flow for you,

trans-unit.source: check out [the types of apps you can build with app model v2.0](active-directory-v2-flows.md).
trans-unit.target: check out [the types of apps you can build with app model v2.0](active-directory-v2-flows.md).

trans-unit.target: Build Single Page Apps with the OAuth 2.0 Implicit Flow

trans-unit.target: Build Daemons or Server Side Processes with the OAuth 2.0 Client Credentials Flow (coming soon)
